captions.text:
Bill Gates: If you can help farmers grow a
lot more, that's a fantastic thing. Most of

these farmers don't have very good seeds,
and they can't afford fertilizer, and they

don't get much advice about what to grow and
how to grow it. So the upside for African

agriculture is it's possible to triple productivity.
So figuring out how a foundation can come

in with pretty modest amounts of money and
get that productivity up, that's our dream.

One thing we do is we help crop research.
We help them create better seeds. But then,

trying to get it to these farmers, particularly
the very poorest farmers. If you're not careful,

if you improve things, the wealthy farmers
near the cities will be the primary beneficiaries.

So asking people how much of your output they
have to consume themselves, and understanding

as the years are good and bad, do you have
years where you have to eat 100%, or where
you're actually not even getting enough?

John: Agriculture is weird because it is a
market, it is a capitalist market, but it's

also one that, you know, in the US, we provide
what amounts to direct assistance with crop

insurance. It's a weird market. It's different
from other markets. In that way, it's a little

bit like health, which is also kind of a market,
but also kind of not.

Bill: Because you want people to get enough
food, because farmers are politically influential,

you're right. Even in rich countries, where
it's only employing 2% of people, the prices

are very distorted. In poor countries, even
more so, because there are some true market

failures, like who's gonna build storage,
or who's gonna provide credit.

John: If A) you didn't make enough money last
year, or B) you spent all of it, then that

becomes impossible. So is one of the ideas
of this cooperative to try to even that out,

so that that capital--you have that capital
going into each season?

Bill: Yeah, that's a huge market failure,
is that typically, banks won't take the credit

risk that they should, because they're going
to have a problem if, let's say, there's a

drought that year. That bank could literally
go bankrupt. So it's not uncorrelated risk,

it's correlated risk that all your borrowers,
their credit is what they grow, and bad weather

could make every single one of them unable
to repay that. Teaching people what seeds

to use, the idea that if you buy hybrid seed
instead of using your leftover seed, that

that's a huge payoff. It takes a while for
people to be used to that. If you happen to

do that the year when the rain doesn't come,
you're gonna be very sorry.
John: Right.

Bill: ...because you're gonna have this debt
that you may never be able to pay off.

John: Can foundations, can we really insulate
against that risk?

Bill: Well, the Mexican government has done
cash support, and they can adjust that based

on whether the weather's been bad or good.
If the government does these things well,

it essentially can come in and play an appropriate
type of crop insurance type role. There is

this idea of micro-insurance, you know, on
your cell phone, learning what price you should

get, getting more advice, even being able
to take a photo of something and having somebody

say, you know, what's going wrong with your
plants. The only thing working against these

farmers is climate change. Every factor is
working in favor of farmer output, self-sufficiency,

better storage, you know, amazing seeds, particularly
if we can use advanced techniques, but climate

change is working against them. So mostly,
it's a positive story.

title: Bill Gates and John Green Discuss Agriculture

comments.author: ed perez

comments.text:
Unfortunately, while I adore the thought behind these efforts, I have to 
disagree with the methods. Hybrid seeds work well, yes. But they are a much 
larger risk in developing agriculture systems -- These systems have 
practices and methods that shouldn't be ignored and systematically replaced 
with green revolution tech. Also, by switching to hybrid crops, we all lose 
biodiversity as breed after breed becomes lost to us in favor of the hybrid 
seeds. Also, hybrid seeds only work once. After the crop is harvested, the 
seeds cannot be saved and used again; instead the farmer has to buy more 
seeds, meaning that the farmer must get enough western money to buy the 
seeds again, though he/she might prefer to trade their goods or use local 
currencies. This sounds amazing in theory, but in practice all it does is 
force farmers to be dependent on western businesses, which is not a 
sustainable practice nor will it allow development of an agricultural 
system in the country. ﻿
comments.author: Laurel Petrulionis

I like what you (John & Bill) are doing, education is a powerful thing.
Are local people in Ethiopia involved in the seed research?  I'd like to 
think some farmers keep using traditional seed replanting methodologies to 
diversify risk inherent in mono cropping with a single strand of hybrid 
seed. It would be even better if the local people in Ethiopia were involved 
in the cross-breeding and control of genes that has been fundamental to 
farming since well before the invention of corn.﻿

comments.author: Catherine B

comments.text:
What Bill Gates talked about is something that the current government of 
the Dominican Republic is doing. They are giving government loans to anyone 
that has land and can grow food at a very attractive 5% annual interest 
that is only there to counteract inflation and administration costs. Each 
group of local farmers gets a government paid accountant and agricultural 
consultant that help them get the most production out of their land. Also, 
the current administration has almost doubled the amount of schools and 
teachers in just 2 years and is currently on their way to providing a full 
8 hours a day of school to a majority of the students (with proper lunches 
served from local businesses). I'm feeling positive about my country of 
birth. ﻿

a very important and worthwhile critique of this approach, I can't possibly

as a technical problem or a problem that can be solved by the likes of the 
Gates Foundation.﻿

comments.text:
Hybrids do not reproduce true to seed if they produce all they produce is a 
stalk with no seed or a couple of seeds that will not reproduce 
productively. The lineage is lost. Hence seed storage banks. GMO's do and 
they are dangerous. Donkey+ horse=mule that is always sterile. Unless they 
are genetically modified. They are working on it. For example pork with 
human dna to make the meat juicier and more tender while remaining leaner.﻿

comments.author: PeaceLove Gishwhes

comments.text:
Bill is completely wrong (or purposely naive) when he states that "the only 
thing working against these farmers is climate change".  The biggest thing 
working against them is a functional lack of property rights throughout the 
region.  This is followed closely by inter-tribal strife and corruption. 
 Once their crops are in the field, they face being thrown of the land 
and/or forfeiture of goods to the local chief, politician, policeman, 
crime-boss, etc.  Throughout much of Africa, there is a tradition of 
kicking a farmers off their land once someone new takes power.  What Bill 
should be working on is codifying property rights throughout Africa.   ﻿

I haven't seen anyone point this out yet.

Poor country's that are allayed with the USA are using the crops that they 
grow and sending almost all of it to the U.S. The U.S. Then uses it, not to 
feed themselves, but to feed their animals in slaughter houses. If every 
one stopped eating meat, these animals would not have to exist and those 
countries would be able to keep the good to feed them selves. Also, those 
extra animals would not overpopulate just like all wild animals once they 
have no threat from humans, they will find a small number of themselves 
once they don't to do bear many offspring. And please. Don't attack me in 
the comments, I'm just pointing something out. ﻿

comments.author: Mark Welschmeyer

comments.text:
I have to call out a small amount of bullshit....

GMO crops won't work, have never worked and will never work in Africa. 

I love the B&MGF and their work, but they got this flat out wrong. They are 
taking the same road that all Western groups have for 50 years. 

And in 10 years, we will once again be staring at a giant pile of fail.

The only way they can sustain that system is to perpetually prop up the 
banks and forgive loans on failed years. Else, doomed to fail. You know 
what you can't do in a bad year when using GMO seeds? Hold back some, 
recover some and plan for next year.

It is an all or nothing game. 

Instead, should enable them with local tools and resources to not need to 
depend on external factors. ﻿
